pros: If you get a good team, wlb can be great.
cons: All team dependent, a lot of fiefs and political maneuvering.

summary: Great place but not for everyone
pros: Process driven work so works well as long as you fit in that process
cons: It’s all about buttering your leadership and play politics to grow

summary: Good manager make the workspace comfortable
pros:
1. A lot of interesting projects in the roadmap which would be playing with different AWS services.
2. Being able to work with excellent engineers and learn from them.
3. Close cooperation between engineer and product manager where you can express your ideas to affect the original design.
4. Decent WLB if you luckily get a good manager.
5. Have a lot of room to be creative.
cons:
- Bad hires consume your energy greatly.
- Tech debt also makes the Ops work painful.
- Customer obsession spirit stresses engineers out sometime.
- Too many inefficient meetings.

summary: Bad Work, decent work life balance.
pros:
1. Brand Name
2. Good Compensation
3. International Relocation Opportunity
cons:
1. Pathetic Work Culture
2. Work is Org and team dependent sometimes it can be really bad.

pros: Great coworkers, most are hard working. If you find the right team, you can work on really challenging problems with wide impact
cons: Terrible culture and compensation philosophy. Can’t keep good talent as a result. No career growth.

pros: Looks good on resume, but that's about it. You get to see how the largest tech company survives with terrible backend.
cons:
bad WLB (duh)
no management
can't learn as much as I thought I would
bad engineering practice all over the place despite being a big tech company
bad benefits (401k, medical, no free food, team events etc)

summary: bad benefits, no raise, no career growth
pros: they pay decent money i love the money they give me
cons: rto5 and no benefits other than 50$ a month phone bill and no career growth

summary: Seems very team to team but mine has been great
pros: If you can find a good team the comp is good and work is interesting. Also great for resume. I’d look for teams that have low turnover (mine has many people that have been on the same team for 10+ years). Lots of resources to work with and smart folks to learn from.
cons: Bad teams exist. Work isn’t always as exciting as it might be elsewhere

pros:
- Work with generally smart and ambitious people
- If you have the right manager, you will grow and promote relatively fast
- Comp
cons:
- PIP
- WLB is super hot and cold in my experience. 
- if you have the wrong manager or bad relation, expect to be in focus
- everything little thing is a microservice (pro or con depending on how you like to work)

summary: It depends so much on leadership
pros: Can learn a lot about industrious standards in one of the biggest tech companies. Could grow even faster with good leadership. Otherwise could be a disaster.
cons: Benefits is not good and most teams have daily stand up.

summary: Good on resume terrible long term
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow and mobility internally if you join the right team
cons: Lots of problems with company culture, top down management and unnecessary processes

pros:
- Pay
- New office
- Free shuttle service
- Large amount of data
cons:
- Old technologies
- A lot of internal dependencies with poor documentations and require mouse clicking
- Feel like doing your job but there is no Google search to use
- Manager resists AI

pros: Its a big company so you can have impact but limited scope.
cons: Leadership is driving it to the ground, they need to be more in touch with the employees

pros: straightforward promos till L5, easy to change teams if you try
cons: culture can be terrible with a bad team, wlb also pretty bad

pros: big name which helps to open the doors to other big techs, not low pay
cons: bad wlb, politics, toxic management. not very good benefits. not caring about employees

pros: Good for career development, good comp, can be pretty chill if you get lucky with your team
cons: Besides comp there are none of the regular big tech benefits. Culture is bad, management is bad, and there’s an absurd level of bureaucracy

summary: Great for a first job in terms of growth but work life balance is not sustainable
pros: You can learn 2 years worth in 1 year at Amazon. Very fast pace
cons: Managers are micromanaging constantly. Oncall load is unmanageable due to project deadlines needing to be met. Operations is often overlooked.

pros: There are equally amount of crazy smart and dumb people amount, but sure you do get to learn a lot if wanted, you just need to know your way around.
cons: Recently been seeing more uninformed and uneducated decisions the upper management made. Maybe it’s a trend anywhere else too, as the tech fairytale has coming to a low.

pros:
Lots of scope at SDE3
WLB various drastically per team. AWS is almost guaranteed to be bad
cons: Less pay compared to market for amount of scope. RTO is RTO

pros:
1. Strong ownership culture
2. High scale, real world problems
3. Talent density
4. Career opportunities
cons:
1. Very heavy process
2. Organisational complexities > technical complexities 
3. No benefits perks

pros:
Access to bleeding edge technologies 
Ability to go deep into industry or technology
cons: It’s Amazon so constantly having to prove yourself and constant org change

pros: Engineering culture is not bad, PTO plus Sick day can easily get u over 20Days+
cons: Back stab culture, trying to move fast but blocked by lot of process

summary: Compensation almost outweighs the exhausting slog to get anything done
pros: The compensation is great, the tools available to complete your work are consistently top-notch (as long as it's not AI).
cons: The company has been on a culture slide since the hiring freeze. The lack of mobility broke all the things that made Amazon a fun, vibrant place to work. Everyone now stays in their role and fiefdoms are growing at each turn.

pros:
Really good experience
High on ownership
High of customer obsession
Best place for freshers and mid engineers to get full experience
Pay is very good
cons:
Lack of work life balance
Oncall is extremely heavy in some teams

pros: Great resume builder and the writing culture is a beneficial form of communication
cons: The devices team is poorly managed and the FireTV customer experience is unsatisfactory in

summary: It used to be a great place to work for
pros: The people are amazing, always ready to help. A lot of resources.
cons: Terrible manager, constant pressure and changes. Micro managing has become a new way to measure success

pros: Competitive compensation and work life balance is good on my team.
cons: There are frequent PIPs, ownership reorganizations, and politics. A lot of projects get scrapped.

summary: Good pay due to stock growth - WLB mixed based on org
pros: You can do well from the increase in stock price over the years.
cons: Work life balance can vary a lot based on the org / team and some orgs are toxic.

summary: Good money but you will suffer
pros:
Good compensation; Great employees and mentors (however only a handful of them);
Nice perks
cons: If you have a bad manager prepare yourself to burnout and wish to quit every single day. Bar is getting lower each day and the culture it’s completely rotten at this point.

pros: If you find the right team in the right org, you can have lots of interesting problems, great WLB, and ample opportunity for growth. The company culture also rewards those who push back against decisions made by higher ups.
cons: Amazon as a whole does a poor job at rewarding their top performers. Their processes and internal bureaucracy are set up with the assumption that people’s performance will cluster somewhere around the mean. This is true most of the time, but whenever you get someone who is truly exceptional, they are held back by these processes and pushed away from the company as a result. In the end, you end up with a collection of people who are all better than average, but anyone who is a genius leaves.
